metadata.title: Three SEO strategies that matter most in 2020
metadata.description: Now that 2020 is here, it’s pretty remarkable to look back at the previous decade in search and see how much things have changed. There were some heavy algorithm updates over the past year and we’ve also got some major search trends that are already changing the way SEOs need to optimise their campa…
metadata.author: Dave Colgate

metadata.title: ASA shows SEO firm who is boss in gender stereotyping row
metadata.description: A poster campaign addressing female London Underground passengers has been banned by the Advertising Standards Authority for perpetuating gender stereotypes.
metadata.author: John Glenday

sections: Do you realise that the moonbase-and-space-travel future of
(I do still have the Eagle Transporter model I bought as a child, though…)
OK, I know you came for the fresh SEO updates, not personal ramblings. Sorry. I'm slipping into my anecdotage.
If you've been trained by me, you'll know this. But this reinforces what I've been saying - think less about keywords, more about
Mummy, don't take away my keywords…
The article below feels a little bit like clutching at straws. It's clear that the direction of travel is towards
being the critical element of search not keywords. I've said that before in this very post. I might yet say it again.
But a whole industry that has built up around keywords isn't going to let go easily. So, here they find a crumb of comfort in an official video from Google.

New year, new core update. On January 13th Google made one of its major core updates - but we don't have any information on specific changes yet. That'll come in the next few days, as SEOs analyse what they see:
When this happens, you want to pay careful attention to your search analytics, to see if you've been impacted.

This is a wierd one (as seems common with SEO blogs). The main article makes a bunch of assertions that aren't really backed up by the quotes from the Google employee he uses. In essence, the core message here is twofold:
No, just putting keywords in headings won't help you rank better
However, well-written sub-headings, which are informative to the reader, will also help Google understand the content better, and thus rank it for appropriate keywords.
In other words: use subheadings - but write them for the reader's benefit, and get the SEO benefit for free.
Here's a couple of prediction posts about what SEO changes are coming our way…
If you've got this far, you can enjoy an SEO agency making a complete sexist arse of itself:
If you find the resources on this site useful, please
